Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cybermanufacturing: Real-Time Scheduling in Networked 3D Printers

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is widely believed that the arrival of 3D printers in the 21st century will pave the way for the Maker revolution. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is aimed at investigating fundamental theoretical and practical issues in the cloud-based utilization of an ensemble of heterogeneous networked 3D printers. The development of cloud-based scheduling algorithms is expected to be important for several cyber-manufacturing systems. Additionally, the theoretical and practical insights developed for the decentralized 3D printing-as-a-service paradigm may have a significant impact on the manufacturing ecosystem at large. Several students are expected to directly and indirectly benefit from the research and enhanced curriculum.

This two-year research effort will focus on developing a fundamental understanding of optimal job assignment in networked 3D printers. Specific objectives of the work include data collection and analysis of heterogeneous 3D print jobs on an existing test bed at University of Maryland, design of optimal routing, batching, and scheduling algorithms to minimize job completion times by efficient decentralized resource utilization, and deployment of the algorithms on a virtual simulator and existing 3D printing infrastructure at University of Maryland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, networked 3D printers were modeled as distributed systems that can communicate with each other to optimize an appropriately defined joint cost function. The intellectual merit of the project is a methodology for distributed optimization of a cost function when these distributed or decentralized systems are interconnected over communication networks. Furthermore, the cost to be optimized depends on the states of a multitude of the distributed/decentralized systems. The accomplished work develops a novel algorithm for solving this problem when there are communication delays in inter-agent communication. The delays are a manifestation of the unreliability of communication networks, such as wireless networks, especially over long-distance communications. The proposed approach allows the ability to handle arbitrary and unknown constant communication delays in the distributed optimization problem. The results are also extended to the case when there are constraints on the distributed optimization problem.

 

The results are broadly applicable to a wide variety of practical optimization problems across disciplines such as finance, robotics, energy systems, machine learning among others.  Communication lag is a common phenomenon and the accomplished work can provide new insights into the ability to handle delays in such distributed optimization problems. The project also resulted in the technical training of a graduate student and influenced several other students across the university. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Nikhil Chopra
